body:
When you make an attack roll and get a natural 20 (the d20 shows 20), you hit regardless of your target's Armor Class, and you have scored a “threat,” meaning the hit might be a critical hit (or “crit”). To find out if it's a critical hit, you immediately make an attempt to “confirm” the critical hit—another attack roll with all the same modifiers as the attack roll you just made. If the confirmation roll also results in a hit against the target's AC, your original hit is a critical hit. (The critical roll just needs to hit to give you a crit, it doesn't need to come up 20 again.) If the confirmation roll is a miss, then your hit is just a regular hit.

A critical hit means that you roll your damage more than once, with all your usual bonuses, and add the rolls together. Unless otherwise specified, the threat range for a critical hit on an attack roll is 20, and the multiplier is ×2.
name: Critical Hits
url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Combat/Actions In Combat/Standard Actions/Attack/Critical Hits

sections.body: Precision damage (such as from a rogue's sneak attack class feature) and additional damage dice from special weapon abilities (such as flaming) are not multiplied when you score a critical hit.
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Combat/Actions In Combat/Standard Actions/Attack/Critical Hits/Exception
sections.name: Exception

sections.body: Sometimes your threat range is greater than 20. That is, you can score a threat on a lower number. In such cases, a roll of lower than 20 is not an automatic hit. Any attack roll that doesn't result in a hit is not a threat.
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Combat/Actions In Combat/Standard Actions/Attack/Critical Hits/Increased Threat Range
sections.name: Increased Threat Range

sections.body: Some weapons deal better than double damage on a critical hit (see Equipment).
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Combat/Actions In Combat/Standard Actions/Attack/Critical Hits/Increased Critical Multiplier
sections.name: Increased Critical Multiplier

sections.body: A spell that requires an attack roll can score a critical hit. A spell attack that requires no attack roll cannot score a critical hit. If a spell causes ability damage or drain (see Special Abilities), the damage or drain is doubled on a critical hit.
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Combat/Actions In Combat/Standard Actions/Attack/Critical Hits/Spells and Critical Hits
sections.name: Spells and Critical Hits
